title: Brexit donor Arron Banks to cash in on higher car premiums as he looks to expand his insurance group
text:
Brexit donor Arron Banks is planning to raise capital to expand his car insurance group so he can cash in on the rising cost of premiums.

The Bristol-based entrepreneur, who claims to be worth £100million, owns the GoSkippy and Vavista car insurance brands through his Eldon Insurance Services group.

The firm’s pre-tax profits almost trebled from £2.5million to £6.5million last year as revenues rose 13.3 per cent to £88million.

Brexit donor Arron Banks said he is looking to boost his firm’s share of the market

Banks said he is looking to boost his firm’s share of the market – currently around 2 per cent – to ‘capitalise on rising car insurance prices’.

He added: ‘We are delighted with the increase in turnover and profit at Eldon Insurance and we will be looking to raise capital to expand the business.’

The tycoon previously announced plans to float Eldon on the stock exchange in a move that would value the company at £250million.

Last week, he would not confirm whether he is still planning a stock market listing or how much he hopes to raise from investors.

In recent months, Banks has consolidated Eldon’s car insurance and claims handling businesses under a new UK-based parent company, Somerset Bridge Group. Previously, the parent company was based offshore on the Isle of Man.

Banks has been cleared of wrongdoing regarding his £8million donation to the Leave.EU campaign through his offshore firm Rock Holdings.
description: Brexit donor Arron Banks is planning to raise capital to expand his car insurance group so he can cash in on the rising cost of premiums.
authors: Harriet Dennys For The Mail On Sunday
